Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Another Era, Another Place By J S Robinson
PoemEnglish:
Another Era, Another Place
I run my thumb across a boulder,
shouldering out of Lough Oughter,

nubbed with little crinoid ossicles
fragmented from sea-lily stalks.

Not flowers but animals that trawled
their five, ten, thirty pinnules

through warm and shallow waters
back when Ireland was a coral reef.

Now in the Marshall Islands,
present-day Pacific Ocean,

living crinoids pulse and ripple
in the currents, feathered arms

striped and dappled: yellow,
maroon, white, golden-orange,

pinkish-purple, cream and green
still alive and breeding well.

In limestone traces crinoid heads
nod on their articulated stems –

exotic sea-flowers trapped in
silver-tone on time’s slow film.

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Backbone By Tom Conaty
PoemEnglish:
“It steadies me to tell these things” (from Squarings 32, “Seeing Things” by Seamus Heaney)

I

More than a metaphor for a Burren Park,
these stony sea pictures
of my backbone,
MRI cave paintings.

More than a soundtrack -
“Where Corals Lie”
playing in my ears
to allay the fears of

hemmed in,
strafing magnets,
pummelling protons, knocking me
off frequency.

II

An organised band of weather,
on a Gulf Stream,
coming in off the Atlantic.
Precipitation,
peppering the land,
raining down with a sculptor’s hand
hammer and chisel
pelt and peal and pull.

And stone gives way
to the siege,
slow dissolving time.

Osteoporosis of limestone
yields
to the weight of water.

Clint and gryke,
paving the way,
stepping stones of the soul.

The wind out here
would rattle you,
if you were on your own.

And yet being on your own
and being alone
and listening to

the delirium of air
is all there is
to settle you

III

Uisce faoi thalamh

Fissure of gryke
and the bottleneck-glug
of gargoyle gargling water.

Runnels of rain,
anterograde flow
through sphincters of light.

Hidden rivers coursing
in veins and arteries
under the skin.

Bone and stone
are only skin deep,
kin deep

Exfoliating
dissolving, absolving,
shedding light

on this border,
where drumlines are written,
beating out the bardo,

liminal lines between
what’s seen above,
hidden below.

IV

The Burren song sings
to “Where Coral’s Lie”

inwards
and
downwards.

Symphony of stone,
ad lib of flood waters

in the dark cave,
making it hard to say

who’s calling.

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Cailceach / Cuilcagh by Séamas Mac Annaidh
PoemEnglish:
Ní bhíonn tú ag súil
Le míol mór a fheiceáil
Caite suas ag barr láin
Ar leaba den fheamainn brioscánach
Ar an trá fholamh idir neamh agus an Cabhán.

Tá eagla ort
Go bhféadfadh sí a bheith beo
Is go ngeitfeadh a craiceann
In arraingeacha an bháis,
Nó go mbainfeadh sí smeach as a heireaball
Is go gcaithfeadh sí muid isteach
I gceann den iliomad aibhneacha móna
A shileann óna taobhanna réabtha
Atá breactha le bairneacha agus feamainn
Agus na coilm ghránna a fuair sí
Ó thaincéirí ola, eangacha,
Agus na harpúin nár bhuail i gceart í.

Ach ná bíodh aon imní ort,
Tá sí chomh marbh le creag
Agus beo leis na feithidí a ritheann
Agus leis na héanacha
A ghiobann agus a phiocann leo,
Ó bhinn bhrúite a headáin,
Agus thar a droim fada leathan
Síos go deireadh a heireabaill
Na mílte as seo.

Mo dhúshlán duit amharc isteach
Sa súil ollmhór oscailte s’aice,
Atá dubh, fuar agus ag sileadh,
Mar atá na mílte poll phortaigh
Atá ag cur thar maoil le rúin.
Nó smaoinigh ar a béal agus na hamhráin
Nach gcluinfear arís.

Ní shílfeá go bhféadfeá a gualainn ollmhór
A dhreapadh, nó fiú a thuiscint,
Nó tá sé róchóngarach, agus fliuch agus sleamhain.
Ach féach, tá an t-eangach níolóin a ghabh í
Sínte trasna na trá agus suas taobh na sléibhe s’aici.

Ní mór dúinn, mar sin, dreapadh
Céim ar chéim, go barr,
Ár n-anáil a fháil linn,
Agus féachaint thart orainn
Go buíoch agus le hiontas
Nó ní bheidh muid chomh cóngarach seo arís
Do mhíol mór sléibhe beo.

_______________

You don’t expect to see
A great she whale
Served up on a bed of crispy weed
At the high tide line
On a lonely strand between Cavan
And heaven.

You fret that she still might be alive
And liable to twitch her skin in death
Or flick her huge tail and send us flying
Into one of the peaty rivers
That flow from her broken sides
Patterned with barnacles and weeds
And scars ever given by oil-tankers,
Fishing-nets, and harpoons that mostly missed.

But don’t worry, she’s as dead as stone can be,
But alive with insects that crawl over her,
And birds that pick and peck their way
From the battered cliff of her brow
Along her long broad back
To somewhere else faraway.

Dare you look into her enormous open eye,
Black, cold and seeping like a thousand bogholes,
Brimful of secrets, or think of that mouth,
Her songs now silent.

You’d think her massive shoulder insurmountable,
Slippery and wet, too close to comprehend,
But look, the nylon filament that entrapped her
Has been stretched across the strand
And up her mountain side.

So together we must climb, step by step,
To stand at the very top, catch our breath,
And stare around in grateful wonder,
For this is a close as we’ll ever get
To a real live mountain whale.
Poem Irish:

Tá eagla ort Go bhféadfadh sí a bheith beo Is go ngeitfeadh a craiceann In arraingeacha an bháis, Nó go mbainfeadh sí smeach as a heireaball Is go gcaithfeadh sí muid isteach I gceann den iliomad aibhneacha móna A shileann óna taobhanna réabtha Atá breactha le bairneacha agus feamainn Agus na coilm ghránna a fuair sí Ó thaincéirí ola, eangacha, Agus na harpúin nár bhuail i gceart í. But don’t worry, she’s as dead as stone can be, But alive with insects that crawl over her, And birds that pick and peck their way From the battered cliff of her brow Along her long broad back To somewhere else faraway. Residence: Florencecourt Primary School, Florencecourt, Co. Fermanagh

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Devenish Island- My Family in the Vertigo of Lockdown By Anthony J Quinn
Title English: Devenish Island: My Family in the Vertigo of Lockdown
PoemEnglish:
I
We left a note in the hotel guest book for the children to find and headed for the boat. We were leaving a hard-edged border for an island that lurked in the rain and drifted out of focus. I grabbed a tricorn hat and a cape, and you packed a tent because you needed a roof over your head to write. The country was emerging from lockdown and growing increasingly deranged. A desolate, distracted time, which you wrote into a book and published on your phone, while I sent out messages for help and texts to a great many people. We waded through months of fuzzy yellow moons and got out of our depth at the bottom of the garden. New variants, conspiracies and vaccines emerged. Our home was a shipwreck hitched to the four horsemen of the Apocalypse. School became a corner of the bed surrounded by candles and oil diffusers where our daughters wrote journals in luxuriant colours and texted updates on their group chats. You kept assessing and asserting your ranking on Twitter and Facebook and fell into some very dark places. It wasn’t the virus but the phone that was making you ill. You were going mad with cabin-fever and conspiracy theories and trying to take us all down, doing lengths in the rain and wallowing alfresco in search of visionary surfaces. You needed a new space to think, so we took to Lough Erne and its watery brink like the migrant monks of old.

II
 A rough crossing, we had, sailing the highway of wild saints. Such a combination of seasickness and mystical visions. You quoted Yeats with a dangerous gaze while I steered north, my heart in my mouth. Ahead of us lay a whale-backed island and a primeval panorama of forested shores. We found a navigable channel and ran hard into a grotto of willow and alder. St Molaise was there for the official reception party, being photographed by Time magazine. His monastery was a refuge for mothers and fathers in danger of going under, and people like him, who’d given up ordinary life for art. We did the ten-day quarantine, obeyed all the restrictions, and moved in with the others. Among them were a burlesque queen with a PhD from New Orleans, a talking parrot and a radical poet who shuffled about in carpet slippers. The evenings we spent in the shebeen by the shore surrounded by melancholy angels. St Molaise orchestrated a cabaret and collected the rent. It seems rather bizarre, but we weren’t being eccentric. The times were odd, not us. What impressed me the most about our host weren’t his deadpan tales of crossing the Irish Sea in a bathtub, or his three-day solo missions in the Atlantic, not even his ‘incidents’ with sea monsters, walruses and whales, but his battles with boredom. He made isolation seem so absurdly cool, with his flinty smile and Latinate drawl. He scoffed at the tameness of our pandemic and quoted from Marianne Moore – ‘The cure for loneliness is solitude’.

III
 Under his benevolent gaze, we felt safe, displaced from the world on Devenish Island, cocooned with our new friends, while the modern world floated offensively by. When night fell, I peered out at the lough but most of it had vanished. All that remained was the tell-tale ripple of an approaching boat. I listened to its wave breaking on the shore and tried to define the shape of the craft and how many people were on board, while you rolled over and went back to sleep. Our children were searching for us under an effulgent night sky, where myriad constellations jostled for space amid dark-spined beasts and other strange life forms. By morning it was late by anyone’s standards. Molaise dove into the lough and tempted us down to its darkest cellars. The monastery dissolved leaving only its shell, and the cells that held it together burst and decayed. The great church broke like a whale, and the monks swept through our colony with their birch scourges until our sins lay shriveled in the grasses like little birds. We were one part of a compass, planted and firm, while our children roved and circled the shore. Later, they found us half-smothered in a wilderness of blackthorn, bracken and gorse. The purpose of our flight was unclear even to us. A mixture of diversion and distraction, confusion and loss. We called out our children’s names and our tongues changed shape. The new sounds that emerged from our mouths flowed like water discovering its path, like laughter tumbling in the waves, where our children were swimming and waiting for us.

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Gortmaconnell By Morag Donald
PoemEnglish:
I wander Gortmaconnell’s wild and gentle lands
Feel the tension dissolve within
The limestone landscape.
A patchwork of moorland, rock and sheltered meadow
Sinkholes and drumlins, best seen in evening light
When I’m moved to ponder

Immovable glacial erratics
Silhouette the skyline.
Boulder fields, cleared by man and horse
Build boundaries from blood, sweat and tears
Beneath a sky that puts all in perspective.
Wind blasted blackthorn leans.
Wild horses gently graze.
Feral goats keep a watchful eye.
You in your space. Me in mine.
Deep moss quilts the rocks
Below the hazel bowers
Where primrose peeps and tender wood sorrel blooms

The Owenbrean rushes past
Lichen painted stones of every colour
Heather moor, hawthorn and sphagnum sponge.
Then dives deep into the porous stone,
Repository of the dead,
Through dark places, seldom seen
And joins her sisters, Sruh Croppa and Aghinrawn
Forming in friendship the Cladagh.

Climbing to the viewpoint, I see
All of life is here.
Sinkholes of loss, drumlins of memory,
Hardened, wind scoured places, persistent rock.
Shelter for tenderness. Wildness and order
And the river of friendship with the land.

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Hen Harrier At Big Dog By Dara McAnulty
PoemEnglish:
My young shin gouged hard by glacial till
Did little to keep me from you.
Falling deep into your rowan berried heart
You all at once trapped and freed me.

Bleeding, I spiralled up Sceolan’s back
Stopping only to fill the pain
With mellow bilberries erratically plucked.
Driven up by the atmosphere of wind

Resting on your sleeping heathered head
I lean into the unsettling.
And watch in disbelief as you propel out
From your engine room tree-passage.

Jet-tipped you levitate, scythe the clouds,
Breaking the air with your wing tips.
The power rush of your ageless building flight
Stops and settles the flow of blood.

We aged instantly together then.
Growing into your settled sand,
I pivot between myth, fact, nature and love.

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Marble Arch by Maria McManus
PoemEnglish:
Don’t think
that nothing good, nor beautiful
can ever come from darkness, from difference:
antagonists,
friction,
a mismatch of opposites –
stone and water
water on stone.

Step in
to the earth’s cold breath,
its blind cool intimacy,
its deep workings,
pearls, cathedrals –
the hidden veins
of its fractured history,
a mystery of patience
time
alchemy.

Residence: Curravagh National School, Glangevlin, Co. Cavan

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Meditation On Lough Oughter By Noel Monaghan
PoemEnglish:
Span of water,
scatter of islands,
Flood of light from the lake.
Attune yourself to a new rhythm,
Let the lake-water go through its motions,
The oar blades cut the steel-grey light,
Up and down of boats and cots
Ripple and popple of lake-water.

Let the lake-water throw light on the past,
Riddle-me-ree of history
Rise and fall of fortunes,
A Middle Age Commedia dell’Arte
de Lacy, Magnifico O’Reilly, il Capitano O’Rourke
Constantly juggling for power
All the spilt blood
At Clough Oughter Castle,
Bishop Bedell imprisoned there.

Further down on Trinity Island
Desolate, wild and lonely,
Monks in white habits
Sang Laudes to the faint light of dawn
Monks intent on growing halos,
Welcomed pilgrims and the poor,

Curve of limestone teeth
Above the door
Tangle and Twist
Curlicue and Squiggle
Of the stones
Nights of long silence
Cells lit by the stars.

Times change
They lost their patrons. It wasn’t easy.
Mayhem and madness prevailed.
Local wars, famine, bubonic plague,
Weather bad and harvest late,
The ornate doorway to their church,
Snatched and lodged in Kilmore.
Unruliness in the order
Hunger for money and lust
A string of Stenterello Sheridans as Priors,
Bishops and Abbots dressed up as shepherds
Proctor Brady, with pockets full of tithes.

Lough Oughter is a different prayer now.
You can be alone with the silence and the swans.
Lough Oughter will tell you:
Who you were, who you are...
Shadows cross the lake-water,

There’s that open invitation to search
The deep and dark abyss,
All the way down to the mudstones
And the first bones of fish.

The ruins of the castle and priory
Continue to swap stories
Ruins to endure
Like ghosts of tomorrow.
© 2021

Residence: Florencecourt Primary School, Florencecourt, Co. Fermanagh

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Shape-Shifting By Helen Shay
PoemEnglish:
They say I did it. But then
they say that about every woman,
who is inevitably labelled ‘witch’.
Yet perhaps it does all start with us,
our magic –creation, blame, change.

It has led me here to the top
of this small mountain, whence
I peregrine myself into 360 degrees
of cauldron-gaze, fixing all that surrounds me.

This is world enough and time.
Lough Nabrickboy cradles sediment
of glacial past, secrets to unlock for all
who dare cross the causeway back
into age of ice, before damsel and dragon
flies danced so courtly here. While above,
green-brown hues stretch into spruce
and red deer keep safe in the forest.

Yet Bran and Skeola hounded me here.
But it was I who led them, transforming
myself into a hind, as women do
from Iphigenia to Sadhbh, to evade
slaughter and violation.
To keep our power.

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Smiotaire/ Knapper by Seamus O' hUltacháin
PoemEnglish:
I bhfad bhfad sular thosaigh amazon.com nó Vistaprint
Ag cur a n-ofrálacha laethúla fríd an cibearspás chugainn
Rinn’ sé a ghnó agus léirigh sé toradh a chuid oibre
Ar fud an tírdhreacha charstaigh seo.
Le súil ghéar don trádáil scrúdaigh sé na h-aillte
Ag measúnú bua na cloiche dá chustaiméirí uilic.
D’oirfeadh an dubh-sheirt thriopallach crochta os cionn na fuíll-leaba abhann
Do chinn sleá agus cinn saighde
An bhreochloch in Ailt na nDraoithe an rud fá choinne teinte
Na cnapóga grianchloiche sna nóidíní ubhchruthacha
Ar imeall Log na bhFiach
An rud a thaitin leis an bpobal do na gréibhlí pearsanta.
Mar sin smiot sé is smut sé
Scealp sé is shnasaigh sé
Is sciomraigh sé
Go dtí gur bheoigh is gur bhreoigh an mín-chriostal
Faoi sholas na gealaí mall-Bhealtaine.
Is ansin thug sé faoina mhórshaothar
Is bhronn bláthfhleasc de bhia beadaí ar déithe na cloiche lómhaire
Crúbóga portáin crosfhite le micrilití agus iontaisithe coiréil
Neas-suite le poipíní buí Breatnacha agus aiteal ársa síorghlas
Sméar mhullaigh ar shaothar a shaoil
Ar fheasacht a ghnoithe
Agus ar fhoirfeacht a dháin
"I bhfad bhfad sular thosaigh amazon.com nó Vistaprint
Ag cur a n-ofrálacha laethúla fríd an cibearspás chugainn
Rinn’ sé a ghnó agus léirigh sé toradh a chuid oibre
Ar fud an tírdhreacha charstaigh seo.
Le súil ghéar don trádáil scrúdaigh sé na h-aillte
Ag measúnú bua na cloiche dá chustaiméirí uilic.
D’oirfeadh an dubh-sheirt thriopallach crochta os cionn na fuíll-leaba abhann
Do chinn sleá agus cinn saighde
An bhreochloch in Ailt na nDraoithe an rud fá choinne teinte
Na cnapóga grianchloiche sna nóidíní ubhchruthacha
Ar imeall Log na bhFiach
An rud a thaitin leis an bpobal do na gréibhlí pearsanta.
Mar sin smiot sé is smut sé
Scealp sé is shnasaigh sé
Is sciomraigh sé
Go dtí gur bheoigh is gur bhreoigh an mín-chriostal
Faoi sholas na gealaí mall-Bhealtaine.
Is ansin thug sé faoina mhórshaothar
Is bhronn bláthfhleasc de bhia beadaí ar déithe na cloiche lómhaire
Crúbóga portáin crosfhite le micrilití agus iontaisithe coiréil
Neas-suite le poipíní buí Breatnacha agus aiteal ársa síorghlas
Sméar mhullaigh ar shaothar a shaoil
Ar fheasacht a ghnoithe
Agus ar fhoirfeacht a dháin

________________________

Long long before amazon.com or Vistaprint
Began to send us their daily offerings through cyberspace
He plied his trade across this limestone escarpment
With a keen eye for business he scanned the cliffs
Figuring out what would be the best stone
For his various customers
The dark chert festooned across the now dry river bed
Made excellent arrowheads and tool points
That in the Druid’s sacred glen
Was imbued with fire-lighting properties
While the quartzite nuggets from the ovoid nodules
Found in the bread-bowl of Legnaveagh
Really took the people’s fancy for self adornment
So he chopped and he chipped
And he knapped and he nipped
And he flaked and he fashioned
Until finally he finished
By burnishing with a brush the fine crystal
Until it glittered and glowed in the late May moonlight
And then he strung together his masterpiece
And gifted a garlanded gourmet meal to the gods of the quartz quarries
Crab claws interlaced with microliths and fossilised crinoids
Juxtaposed with yellow Welsh poppies and ancient evergreen juniper
‘Chef d’oeuvre’ of his life’s work
His trading nous
And his artistic principles
Poem Irish:

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Source By Rebecca Allen
PoemEnglish:
Falling from heavenly source
Gravity drives droplets
down ever cleansing
into purity of darkness
Gathering below
for time unspecified
Centuries maybe or longer
than mortals can imagine

Intricately percolated and purified
on a journey of least resistance
Congregating capillaries in secret caverns
below the surface
Accumulating essence

She flows, trickles at first
Eventually rising, rising Birthing waters mineral rich
rise to surface pool
The Shannon Pot

Tree circle bows homage, gazing in
and weeping leaves
Meandering seaward
lung-like tributaries delivering
as she glides through
But not yet -
First she will gather and rest
here - a little longer

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · The Artists By Caroline Bracken
PoemEnglish:
i.
 I am the painter, my canvas is wide
 my palette: forest green, earth brown, sky blue, fire red.
 I work night and day in brushstrokes both broad and delicate
 I am invisible to the human eye
 my handiwork evolves over aeons.
 I am wind.
ii.
 I am the sculptor, stone is my medium
  used to shape the landscape into drumlins, valleys.
 I left myself behind in burrens and lakes
  so you would not forget me.
 I am ice.
iii.
 I am the dancer, as light as Swan Lake
 or as loud as Riverdance.
 I leave my footprints in water
  dissolving limestone to form caves.
 I am rain.
iv.
  I am the glassblower, underground
 in the deep earth’s core
 metamorphosis is my game
  I make pegamite and feldspar
  the backbone of Belleek Pottery.
 I am heat.
v.
 I am the outsider artist, not pretty
  like the Cladagh Glen bluebells,
  not spectacular like the Marble Arch caves
 or healing like the Belcoo Holy Well.
 I am heavy, grey and misshapen, thrown here on the edge
  of Cavan Burren by the sculptor.
  They call me erratic, though I never move
 I sit on a limestone pedestal, protect it from erosion
 not that anyone notices.
 My subject is myself, my tools are the other artists.
 I use them to create a self-portrait, eye-niches where your ancestors
  laid their loved ones’ ashes, a moss-covered nose
 and between my base and sandstone form
 a smile.
 I am The Boulder Stone.

Residence: Curravagh National School, Glangevlin, Co. Cavan
Link_URL: North Mapping Services · The Legend of Shannon Pot By Emma McGovern
PoemEnglish:
Trying to find
The Salmon of Wisdom
Angry fish overflowing the pool
Girl lost
Poet_Residence:
Emma McGovern, age 12
6th class, Curravagh National School, Glangevlin, Co. Cavan

Link_URL: North Mapping Services · Turbet Island- An Tairbeirt By Brid Cahill
PoemEnglish:
Sunshine streams through latticed leaves, vibrant green
Paints rustic scene on tranquil Turbet Isle
Where now I stroll the winding wooded paths.
Hard to envision millennia past
When ice held it fast in glacial grip,
And woolly mammoths dug with giant tusks
Dredging sedges for elephant tummies.

Might of ice held sway ‘til shift in earth’s tilt
Warmed frigid land and meltwater began
To mould moraine, create drumlin and lake,
Make meandering Erne to swell and surge
Bearing forefathers here with hunting spear.
Breifne, their kingdom through centuries grew
Forest and farm thriving, river trade too.

When rival clans for supremacy clashed
O’Rourke and O’Reilly hostility
Was Anglo Norman opportunity.
De Lacy, a motte and bailey raised,
Claiming mastery of Gaelic Breifne
But brief was his reign along River Erne,
His settlement town of Tairbeirt would be
In restored O’Reilly territory.

In seventeenth century, Planters came
And gave to Beal Tairbeirt its Anglo name,
A garrison fortress and central square,
Anglican church, spire high on horizon.
Much grandeur still in this once county town,
The Erne at its heart, Turbet Isle the soul
Where ghosts of ancestors close by us roam.
